prep_instructions.name: none
prep_instructions.desc: The ingredient is left unprocessed or uncut, used in its natural state as received (e.g., whole vegetables, raw meat cuts, or intact fruit). No cutting or preparation is applied beyond basic cleaning or trimming.

prep_instructions.name: 10x10mm
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into small, uniform cubes measuring 10 millimeters (1 cm) on each side. Suitable for vegetables, fruits, or tender meats, often used for garnishes or even cooking.

prep_instructions.name: 15x15mm
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are diced into medium cubes measuring 15 millimeters (1.5 cm) on each side. Common for stews or dishes where slightly larger pieces are desired.

prep_instructions.name: 20x20mm
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into larger cubes measuring 20 millimeters (2 cm) on each side. Ideal for hearty dishes like roasts or chunky vegetable medleys.

prep_instructions.name: fine
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are very finely chopped or processed into small, uniform pieces, typically less than 2-3 mm in size. Used for meats, or fruits when a delicate texture is needed (e.g., fine herbs or fruit purÃ©es).

prep_instructions.name: ground
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients (usually meat, but sometimes fruits or vegetables) are mechanically processed into a paste-like consistency using a grinder or food processor. Common for minced meat or fruit bases.

prep_instructions.name: ground - fine
prep_instructions.desc: This is one of the smallest and most common grind sizes.

prep_instructions.name: ground - medium
prep_instructions.desc: Common for burgers, tacos, Bolognese sauce, or shepherdâs pie.

prep_instructions.name: ground - coarse
prep_instructions.desc: A chunkier grind, often used for hearty dishes like chili, stews, or specialty burgers where you want more bite.

prep_instructions.name: grate
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are shredded into small, thin fragments using a grater. Often applied to vegetables (e.g., carrots), fruits (e.g., apples), or even firm meats for specific recipes.

prep_instructions.name: grate - large
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are shredded into small, thin fragments using a grater. Often applied to vegetables (e.g., carrots), fruits (e.g., apples), or even firm meats for specific recipes.

prep_instructions.name: grate - medium
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are shredded into small, thin fragments using a grater. Often applied to vegetables (e.g., carrots), fruits (e.g., apples), or even firm meats for specific recipes.

prep_instructions.name: grate - fine
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are shredded into small, thin fragments using a grater. Often applied to vegetables (e.g., carrots), fruits (e.g., apples), or even firm meats for specific recipes.

prep_instructions.name: fresh
prep_instructions.desc: The ingredient is used in its raw, unprocessed, and freshly harvested or sourced state, without cooking, drying, or freezing. Applies to vegetables, fruits, or meats.
prep_instructions.imperial: Used in its raw unprocessed state
prep_instructions.metric: Used in its raw unprocessed state

prep_instructions.name: whole
prep_instructions.desc: The ingredient is left intact, uncut, and unprocessed beyond basic cleaning or peeling (e.g., a whole carrot, apple, or chicken breast).

prep_instructions.name: brunoise
prep_instructions.desc: A precise, very small dice, typically 1-3 mm cubes, achieved by first cutting into julienne strips and then dicing. Commonly used for vegetables (e.g., carrots, onions) or fruits for garnishes.

prep_instructions.name: chiffonade
prep_instructions.desc: Thin, ribbon-like strips created by stacking and rolling leafy vegetables (e.g., basil, spinach) or herbs, then slicing finely across. Not typically used for meats or solid fruits.

prep_instructions.name: chop
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are roughly cut into irregular, bite-sized pieces without strict uniformity. Applies to vegetables, meats, or fruits for rustic preparations.

prep_instructions.name: chopped fine
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are roughly cut into irregular, bite-sized pieces without strict uniformity. Applies to vegetables, meats, or fruits for rustic preparations.

prep_instructions.name: chopped rough
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are roughly cut into irregular, bite-sized pieces without strict uniformity. Applies to vegetables, meats, or fruits for rustic preparations.

prep_instructions.name: cube
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into uniform, three-dimensional squares, typically larger than a dice (e.g., 1-2 cm or more). Used for vegetables, meats, or firm fruits.

prep_instructions.name: dice
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into small, uniform cubes, typically smaller than a standard cube (e.g., 0.5-1 cm). Common for vegetables, meats, or fruits in precise recipes.

prep_instructions.name: julienne/french-cut
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into long, thin matchstick-like strips, typically 1-2 mm thick and 4-5 cm long. Often used for vegetables (e.g., carrots) or firm fruits; less common for meats.

prep_instructions.name: mince
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are finely chopped into very small pieces, smaller than a chop (e.g., 1-2 mm). Common for vegetables (e.g., garlic), meats, or fruits for pastes or fillings.

prep_instructions.name: slice
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into thin, flat pieces of varying thickness. Applies to vegetables (e.g., tomatoes), meats (e.g., steak), or fruits (e.g., apples).

prep_instructions.name: rondelle
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into round, coin-shaped slices, typically from cylindrical vegetables (e.g., carrots, zucchini) or fruits. Not commonly used for meats.

prep_instructions.name: diagonal
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are sliced at an angle to create elongated, oval-shaped pieces. Often used for vegetables (e.g., carrots) or meats for presentation.

prep_instructions.name: batonnet
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into thick, stick-like pieces, typically 6 mm x 6 mm x 5-6 cm long. Common for vegetables (e.g., potatoes for fries) or firm fruits; less common for meats.

prep_instructions.name: jardiniere
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are cut into baton-like shapes, slightly smaller than batonnet (e.g., 4 mm x 4 mm x 2-3 cm). Used for vegetables in classic French cooking.

prep_instructions.name: macedoine
prep_instructions.desc: Ingredients are diced into small, uniform cubes, typically 5 mm on each side. Used for vegetables or fruits in mixed dishes or salads.

prep_instructions.name: other
prep_instructions.desc: Any processing or cutting method not explicitly listed, specific to the recipe or preparation context.

allergy.name: unknown
allergy.desc: Unable to classify ingredient allergies. Manual intervention is required.

allergy.name: none
allergy.desc: No common food allergy associations.

allergy.name: buckwheat
allergy.desc: Common in Asia, especially Japan (e.g. in soba noodles).

allergy.name: celery
allergy.desc: Celery might sneak into soups, stocks, or seasoning blends.

allergy.name: chilli
allergy.desc: Chilli and garlic are staples in countless cuisines, from sauces to marinades, often unlisted in fine detail.

allergy.name: eggs
allergy.desc: Particularly egg whites, a common allergen in children.

allergy.name: garlic
allergy.desc: Though rare, garlic allergies can occur, leading to symptoms like skin rashes or respiratory discomfort.

allergy.name: gluten
allergy.desc: Gluten, bread and pasta, lurks in processed foods like soups, dressings, or even soy sauce.

allergy.name: lupin
allergy.desc: A legume used in flours and baked goods, notable in Europe.

allergy.name: milk_dairy
allergy.desc: Cows milk

allergy.name: mustard
allergy.desc: Significant in Europe, found in sauces and condiments.

allergy.name: peanuts
allergy.desc: Technically a legume, but listed separately due to its high allergenic potential.

allergy.name: rice
allergy.desc: More prevalent in Asia, though less common globally.

allergy.name: seafood_fish
allergy.desc: Beyond fish and shellfish, allergies to squid or octopus may occur.

allergy.name: sesame
allergy.desc: Widespread in regional cuisine (e.g., tahini, halva).

allergy.name: shellfish
allergy.desc: Crustaceans: Shrimp, crab, lobster & Mollusks: Clams, mussels, oysters, squid.

allergy.name: soybeans
allergy.desc: Soy Beans, Edamame and soy-based products like tofu and soy milk.

allergy.name: sulphur_dioxide
allergy.desc: Sulphur dioxide, a preservative, hides in dried fruits, wines, and some packaged snacks.

allergy.name: tree_nuts
allergy.desc: Includes almonds, walnuts, cashews, pistachios, pecans, hazelnuts, Brazil nuts, etc.

allergy.name: wheat
allergy.desc: A frequent trigger, especially in children.

allergy.name: nightshade
allergy.desc: Nightshades contain alkaloids, but the highest concentration is in the leaves and stem (questionable as an allergen), not the vegetable/fruit. Tomatoes, Potatoes, Eggplant, Peppers, Goji berries etc

recipe_type.name: local
recipe_type.desc: A recipe only available for this recipe. i.e. Local Recipe

recipe_type.name: master
recipe_type.desc: A master recipe. Changes affect all recipes. i.e. Global Recipe.

recipe_type.name: unlinked_master
recipe_type.desc: A recipe that was a master, but unlocked for local use, but can be relinked to a master.
